comments:
I200404200800

In the latest integration build, my workspace frequently enters a state where I
cannot compile. Creating a new workspace fixes the problem, but the problem
occurs frequently enough that it is usually impossible to fully reconstruct my
workspace before the problem recurs and I need to start again.

1. When attempting to build, nothing happens. No dialog is opened and no
progress is shown on the status line.
2. If the new progress view is open, the message "SLEEPING: Open Progress
Monitor" is shown briefly.
3. Clean..., Build Project, Build All, and autobuilds all have this problem.
(With or without Autobuild enabled).
4. Refreshing the workspace and/or restarting Eclipse has no effect.
5. My workspace currently contains many "The project cannot be build until its
prerequisite xxxx is rebuilt." errors. The error markers are not cleared by Clean...
6. There are no exceptions in my log for sessions in which I was having trouble
building. However, the following exceptions occurred during previous sessions,
and I believe that the OutOfMemoryException was thrown during the very last
session before builds stopped working.

Note: the last thing I remember doing before builds permanently stopped working
was changing "Unused Imports" to an error and triggering a rebuild.

I find this happening in I200404220800 too.

Note: I have a workspace that predictably (and permanently) demonstrates this
bug. Let me know if any portions of it would be useful for resolving it.

Stefan - can you not rebuild even after restarting your workspace after a 
reboot?

If you get into a state where no builds happen at all, then this is a Core 
Resources problem for which they have a few PRs.

John, I've dropped the workspace demonstrating the problem into your public
directory.
(may or may not be a duplicate of bug 59836)

Using current HEAD I can compile Stefan's workspace without difficulty. Note
that Project > Clean... did not work at all in last week's builds (see bug
59595).  I am wondering if this was the only problem. If your workspace got into
an inconsistent state (for example due to an OutOfMemoryError during a build),
there was no way to get the builders back into a consistent state. I will leave
this open for now - let me know if you get into this state again with I20040427
or later.

I'm going to chalk this up as either a symptom of the fact that "Clean" did not
work in that build, or as a side-effect of the numerous JDT/PDE build path
problems that have been identified and fixed over the last two weeks.

Please reopen if you can reproduce with I20040505 or later.
FYI, I haven't noticed this problem in the build on the 27th.

I just observed this again in I200405060200

I can send you the workspace if necessary, or can reproduce it on my machine.
This time, I ended up with a problem marker that said:

"Internal compiler error[]java.lang.OutOfMemoryError[][]"

Clean, refresh, build all, and build project all did nothing. Copying the
workspace to a new location and restarting Eclipse did not help.

Although restarting Eclipse did not help, rebooting my machine did. After a
reboot, the same workspace compiled fine. Reducing severity since a workaround
exists.

I don't know if rebooting your computer constitutes a work-around... as a Linux
user, the idea that I have to reboot my computer to fix one program is...
well... a Bad Thing (tm).  (Bad Thing == If it makes me reboot my computer, I
will never run this program again.)

CCing Philippe - It looks like Stefan is getting frequent OutOfMemoryErrors
inside the Java builder, which is leaving his workspace in a very bad state.

Stefan - if you have a workspace demonstrating the problem, please drop it in
the same place that you dropped it last time.

Moving severity back up, as rebooting is certainly not an acceptable workaround.
Marco, are you still seeing this also?

I'm not sure if I'm seeing this right now.  I've had problems building, but I'm
not entirely sure if it's this bug or bug 61397.  So I can't give you a definite
yes.  Sorry for the non-help. :-(
Kent - looks like a good candidate for footprint analyze.
Closing again, as this hasn't been reproduced in M9 or RC1.
